Subject: Geography
Content: Name the location of your selected example of deforestation.

Subject: Geography
Content: Identify two reasons for the current land cover change at your selected location.

Subject: Geography
Content: Describe two ways in which deforestation is assessed at your selected location.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Evaluate the effectiveness of one management technique in response to the impacts
of deforestation at your selected location.

Subject: Geography
Content: For a selected location experiencing melting ice, state the scale of change over a defined period of time.

Subject: Geography
Content:
'The global phenomenon of melting ice sheets and glaciers is the result of the interconnection of natural
processes and human activity."
Discuss, with reference to a selected location. You may use the same selected location chosen for
Question 2.
Use Figure 1 on pages 2 and 3 of the Data Book when responding to Question 4.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Outline one way in which the analysis of satellite images or other forms of remote
sensing would assist the geographer in identifying the land use change at this location.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Select another source of data that the geographer could use in an investigation of the
change in land use at the site in Figure 1. Explain the value of this data source.
Do not use satellite images or other forms of remote sensing in this answer.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Describe one geospatial technology used in your fieldwork investigation at a selected
site involving land use change.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Name your selected country with an ageing population.
Identify two demographic characteristics that support your classification of this country as one with an
ageing population.
Use Figure 2 on pages 4 and 5 of the Data Book when responding to Question 6.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Describe the changing spatial distribution of regions and/or countries that are predicted to experience
natural population decrease between 2000 and 2050.
Use Figure 3 on page 6 of the Data Book when responding to Question 7.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Suggest two reasons for the high proportion of those aged 19 and under in the
population structure of Country A.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Using Country A as an example, explain how a decrease in infant mortality rates could
have an impact on life expectancy levels of the population over several decades.

Subject: Geography
Content: Use Figure 4 on page 7 of the Data Book when responding to Question 8.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Outline the main reasons for variations in population growth as developed in
Malthusian theory.

Subject: Geography
Content: To what extent does the data in Figure 4 support the predictions of Malthus?

Subject: Geography
Content:
Name your selected country with a growing population.
Analyse the causes of the resulting issues and challenges associated with this country's growing
population.
Extra space for responses
Clearly number all responses in this space.
If you use any additional Question and Answer Books to complete your responses, write your student
number on the front cover. At the end of the examination, place the additional Question and Answer
Books inside the front cover of the first Question and Answer Book.
Assessment criteria for extended-answer questions
The extended-answer questions will be assessed against the following criteria, as appropriate:
« application of geographical knowledge and understanding
« demonstration of geographical skills
« description and application of key geographical concepts
« interpretation and analysis of data and other geographical information

Figure 4. Total fertility rate and severe food insecurity for selected countries, 2021
Note: Food insecurity occurs when
a person lacks regular access to
enough safe and nutritious food for
normal growth and development. Food
insecurity is considered to be severe
when, at times during a year, a person
has had to reduce the quantity of their
food and go without food for parts of
day or a whole day.

'The application of geospatial technology has done little to effectively assess and manage
rates of melting ice sheets and glaciers.'
Evaluate this statement with reference to one selected location.

Subject: Geography
Content: Name the location of your selected area of fieldwork.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Outline the land use change that has recently occurred, is underway or is planned for
the near future at your fieldwork location.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Identify and explain how two geographic characteristics have impacted, or are likely
to impact, the land use change at your fieldwork location.

Subject: Geography
Content:
There are many different types of population movement, including:
•	 forced migration
•	 voluntary migration
•	 long-term migration (greater than 10 years).
Describe each of these three types of population movement using different origin and
destination examples.
Forced migration 
Voluntary migration 
Long-term migration 
Use Figure 3 on page 6 of the Data Book when responding to Question 8.

Subject: Geography
Content:
The population represented in Figure 3 is experiencing a demographic dividend.
demographic dividend is a potential boost in economic productivity that can occur when
the number of people in the workforce is growing relative to the number of people outside
the workforce.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Justify, using evidence from Figure 3, that Country A is experiencing a demographic
dividend.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Predict a challenge that this demographic dividend could present for government or
non-government organisations in Country A in the next 30 to 40 years. Justify your
prediction using evidence from Figure 3.

Subject: Geography
Content:
Name your selected country with a growing population.
Discuss the nature of the population trends that have occurred in this country's population structure
over time. Include a sketch diagram(s) to support your response. Do not use Country A from Question 8
in your response.
Space for sketch diagram(s)
